p: Rural communities throughout the USA need evidence-based interventions to reduce the consequences of the opioid epidemic (e.g., HIV and viral hepatitis outbreaks, overdose fatalities) among people who inject drugs (PWID) [ 1– 4]. Syringe services programs (SSPs) are effective structural interventions that have demonstrated public health benefits [ 5– 13]. Through the provision of sterile injection equipment, SSPs prevent the spread of HIV/HCV infections among PWID, resulting in significant cost savings [ 14– 16]. Additionally, SSPs may offer wraparound services, including HIV/HCV testing, naloxone distribution, and linkages to other services [ 17]. Although there is consensus in the literature regarding the benefits of SSPs, most studies examined their implementation in urban areas [ 18]. This creates an important gap in the literature given the ongoing vulnerability for HIV/HCV outbreaks among PWID in rural communities [ 19, 20].
